text: First of all, I think there's a big
difference about
uh American secularism or European
secularism. I mean American American
definition of secularism is not that
they expect religion to die or to people
to be personally
uh uh secular but that there's a belief
that there should be an observation of
separation of church and state into
equal domains that religion ought to be
protected from politics and politics
ought to be protected from religion. In
Europe is a very different definition.
Secularism first of all means that state
will rule over
religion. It will control religion. It
will appoint its
uh clergy. It will control the revenues.
It will control the uh institutions etc.
It would legislate for religious
activity. But also in Europe it goes
beyond just uh separation. There's an
expectation that society that God would
not exist in society that religion would
be a matter of very strictly private
practice and people's religious views
would be private to them and on top of
it that religion itself actually would
reform in a manner to secularize from
within. So some strands of
protestantism, reformed Judaism or the
Vatican 2 reforms in the Catholic Church
were all sort of reflections of this
kind of pressure. Now the question is
which one are we talking about in the
Muslim world and I don't think the
Americans are
clear. It looks to Muslims that the
Americans are not asking for a
separation of church and state. They're
asking Muslims to be more secular
personally than Americans
are. And that's that's part of the whole
problem. I mean, when you and this might
be a misperception, but Muslims say,
"Who are the favorite Muslim thinkers of
Americans? It's always somebody who's
talking about reforming Islam or
nowadays somebody who's actually a
Muslim who's anti-Muslim." Tends to be
the most popular the most popular books.
uh the fact and and also the the the
perception that that America actually
wants to destroy Islam quote unquote. It
is more than destroying Islamic
institutions or Islamic power. It also
there is a perception that what America
really wants from Muslims is not to
believe in Islam. That a good Muslim is
one who doesn't believe in Islam. And
this this has to do with with a
perception that the west really believes
that uh the problem is not just
separation of institutions of church and
state but Islam as a religion is a
problem. It it's pro- jihad it's
extremist it's anti-democratic it's
misogynist etc. And therefore Muslims
should really stop being Muslims. So, so
I think that the whole discourse, the
whole discussion about what is it that
we mean by secularism in the Muslim
world has been itself extremely
corrosive to US relations in the Muslim
world. And it's partly because it's not
properly defined in America as to what
it is that we mean by by secularism.
